title: 112_s3493
content: The "Free Press Act of 2012" may be cited as the official title of the Act. Additionally, a special motion to dismiss is added to Part VI of title 28, United States Code, under the new "CHAPTER 182--SPECIAL MOTION TO DISMISS." The "Free Press Act of 2012" includes provisions for a special motion to dismiss in civil actions involving the news media. This motion can be filed by a representative of the news media if the claim relates to a matter of public concern or a public official. The motion must be filed within 45 days of service in Federal court. The special motion to dismiss in civil actions involving the news media must be filed within 45 days of service in Federal court. If the claim is removed to Federal court under section 4206, it must be filed within 30 days. Amendments to the claim are not allowed until a final order denying the special motion to dismiss is entered. The burden of proof lies with the news media representative to show that the claim falls under the specified criteria, and the party asserting the claim must prove its legal sufficiency. Sec. 4202 Stay of discovery: Upon filing a special motion to dismiss under section 4201, discovery proceedings in the action shall be stayed until a final order is entered on the special motion to dismiss. If the nonmoving party fails to meet the burden required, the claim shall be dismissed with prejudice. Sec. 4203 outlines exceptions for governmental litigation and commercial speech, stating that a special motion to dismiss cannot be filed for claims brought by the Federal Government or the attorney general of a State, or claims arising from statements promoting goods or services. Additionally, Sec. 4204 allows for interlocutory appeals in certain circumstances. Sec. 4204 allows for interlocutory appeals from orders granting or denying a special motion to dismiss under section 4201. Sec. 4205 permits individuals to file a special motion to quash requests for personally identifying information related to statements on public concern or public officials. Sec. 4206 outlines the burden of proof for requests or orders related to personally identifying information. If the movant meets the burden, the nonmoving party must show the claim is legally sufficient and supported by admissible evidence. Failure to meet this burden results in the request being quashed. A civil action in a State court that appears to be a claim described in section 4201(a) can be removed to the district court of the United States by a party seeking to file a special motion to dismiss based on the Constitution or laws of the United States. Removal cannot be requested for third-party or cross claims. If the special motion to dismiss is denied, the case may be remanded back to the State court. When a special motion to dismiss is filed under section 4201, the court may remand remaining claims to the State court. A special motion to quash can be filed in a State court and removed to the district court if it asserts a defense based on the Constitution or laws of the United States. Sec. 4207 outlines the awarding of attorney's fees, costs, and sanctions for prevailing on special motions to dismiss or quash under sections 4201 and 4205. Sec. 4207 allows for the awarding of litigation costs, expert witness fees, and reasonable attorney's fees to the party that responded to frivolous special motions or notices, with exceptions for governmental entities and novel legal questions. The special motion to dismiss or quash may be granted if it involves a novel legal question in favor of the movant. SEC. 3. RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER LAWS. This Act does not override any Federal or State laws that offer equal or greater protection for activities protected by the First Amendment. SEC. 4. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amendments are made to the table of chapters for part VI of title 28, United States Code. Section 182 of the Act introduces amendments to sections 1292(a) and 523(a) of title 28 and title 11 of the United States Code. These changes include provisions for interlocutory appeals related to special motions to dismiss and the nondischargeability of litigation costs, expert witness fees, and attorney's fees awarded by a court under chapter 182. The amendments under chapter 182 of title 28 allow for the awarding of attorney's fees by a court. The Act and its amendments will take effect upon enactment and apply to claims filed after enactment. For claims filed before enactment, the Act applies if no judgment has been entered, and the time periods under specific sections of the United States Code begin on the date of enactment.
